Everybody just plays along with the farce, everybody plays along."-Noam Chomsky  The original context is along the lines of nobody gives heroes recognition or acknowledgment until they're either dead or after they've stopped doing what they do. Then, after the greatness or individuality has stopped, people decide to recognize the individual and perpetually fail to recognize the greatness of current leaders. Hence, "if only we had more people like him." We do. People just don't like admitting other people are better than them, and it's hard to gain popularity. Also, many great minds get discredited before they get a chance to shine. If a person is a plausible threat to a community or organization, that community or orginization will try to discredit them at all costs to preserve their own reputation.
